s: After being signed by Elektra records at the tender age of 15, completing two LPs as The Eric Gales Band, and a third (Left Hand Brand) on House Of Blues Records, Eric Gales returns with his new release "That's What I Am." At 25, Gales redefines himself as a singer, songwriter, and guitarist ...

Gales, Eric - Relentless - Amazon.com Music
s: I was wondering how Eric Gales was going to top his last CD, "The Story of My Life," but somehow he did! This is definitely his best piece of work yet! A great mixture of straight blues and more modern blues-rock songs! His guitar chops and tone are KILLER! This HAS to be the best blues-rock ...

t: Live (CD/DVD) - Gales, Eric - Amazon.com
s: Eric Gales is top notch guitar player! He's a good singer too! I'm a big fan. I just don't care for his lyrics. They don't seem as mature or sophisticated as his guitar playing. I still listen to him for his guitar and vocal performance though. This is a good live album for him.

t: Amazon
s: If you're into Fusion Jazz music with great guitars sessions. Then Eric Gale CDs/records are a must have for your music library. The selection I like on this CD is called "Tonsue Corte". Please check it out.

t: Eric Gales - Good for Sumthin' - Amazon.com Music
s: Known for his upside-down left-handed playing as well as his deeply expressive, soulful vocals, Gales draws comparisons to both Jimi Hendrix and blues legend Albert King! Guest appearances by renegade Zakk Wylde (of Ozzy Osbourne and Black Label Society) and master of the Strat, Eric Johnson, ...

Gales, Eric - The Story Of My Life - Amazon.com Music
s: Eric has developed a unique hybrid blues/rock sound that also draws upon influences as diverse as Albert King and Eric Johnson. A unique amalgam of styles Eric Gales stands head and shoulders among other guitarists in his genre.

t: Gales, Eric - Eric Gales Band | Amazon.com.au | Music
s: OK, so I remember when this album came out. There was a lot of hype over the Eric Gales Band, and music magazines really gave this album a great rating. Too bad I was musically shortsighted in '91 and ignored it because it wasn't a metal album! But, I suppose better late than never.
